text: For Release Upon Delivery
label: BODY

text: TESTIMONY OF
label: HH1

text: KATHRYN E. DICK
label: HH2

text: DEPUTY COMPTROLLER FOR CREDIT AND MARKET RISK
label: HH1

text: COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY
label: HH1

text: BEFORE THE
label: HH1

text: SUBCOMMITTEE ON SECURITIES, INSURANCE, AND INVESTMENT
label: HH1

text: OF THE
label: HH1

text: COMMITTEE ON BANKING, HOUSING, AND URBAN AFFAIRS
label: HH1

text: UNITED STATES SENATE
label: HH1

text: JULY 9, 2008
label: HH2

text: Statement Required by 12 U.S.C. § 250:
label: BODY

text: The views expressed herein are those of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
label: BODY

text: and do not necessarily represent the views of the President.
label: BODY

text: Introduction
label: HH1

text: Good afternoon Chairman Reed, Ranking Member Allard and members of the
label: BODY

text: Subcommittee.  My name is Kathy Dick and I am a Deputy Comptroller for Credit and
label: BODY

text: Market Risk at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC).  I am pleased to be
label: BODY

text: here today to testify at the Subcommittee’s hearing on Reducing Risks and Improving
label: BODY

text: Oversight in the Over-The-Counter (OTC) Credit Derivatives Market.
label: BODY

text: As you know, the OCC charters, regulates, and supervises all national banks.  At
label: BODY

text: the end of 2007, there were 1,709 banks in the national banking system, with total assets
label: BODY

text: of $7.8 trillion; that is one of every five banks in the United States, with 70 percent of all
label: BODY

text: commercial banking assets.  These include the country’s largest, most complex banks, a
label: BODY

text: number of which are significant participants in the derivatives markets.  Although more
label: BODY

text: than 1,000 commercial banks reported holdings of derivatives in their first quarter call
label: BODY

text: report filings, the bulk of derivatives activity within the commercial banking industry is
label: BODY

text: concentrated in a small number of institutions, most of which are national banking
label: BODY

text: organizations.1  It is the OCC’s view that bank derivatives businesses are appropriately
label: BODY

text: concentrated in these large national banks because they have the resources, including risk
label: BODY

text: management expertise and control systems, to control derivatives-related risks in a safe
label: BODY

text: and sound manner.  This concentration also reflects the important role these large
label: BODY

text: national banks serve as financial intermediaries for a wide range of clients who use
label: BODY

text: derivatives to manage and facilitate their business transactions and risk exposures.  Given
label: BODY

text: banks’ role as financial intermediaries, ensuring that the OTC derivatives market operates
label: BODY

text: 1 Please see the attached OCC Quarterly Report on Bank Trading and Derivatives Activities – First Quarter
label: BODY

text: efficiently and effectively is of concern for both the OCC and the banks we supervise.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the OCC spends a considerable amount of time and resources evaluating the
label: BODY

text: risk control systems these banks use to manage risks in derivatives markets.
label: BODY

text: I have structured my testimony to focus on the areas of particular interest to this
label: BODY

text: Subcommittee, as outlined in your June 27, 2008, letter of invitation.  My testimony
label: BODY

text: today will include the supervision of credit derivatives activities in national banks, the
label: BODY

text: work being done to strengthen the infrastructure in the credit derivatives market, the
label: BODY

text: OCC’s view on benefits that may be derived from establishing a central counterparty for
label: BODY

text: clearing credit derivatives and the possible implications of an exchange for credit
label: BODY

text: derivatives, and finally the OCC’s view on the need for additional legislation in this area.
label: BODY

text: First, I will provide background on what credit derivatives are, the size of the
label: BODY

text: credit derivatives market and the volume of this activity in the banks supervised by the
label: BODY

text: OCC.
label: BODY

text: Credit derivatives are financial contracts that allow market participants to take, or
label: BODY

text: reduce, credit risks.  For example, an institution can reduce the credit risk associated with
label: BODY

text: a loan or bond by purchasing credit protection on the obligor using a credit default swap.
label: BODY

text: Similarly, credit default swaps enable financial institutions to manage their credit risk
label: BODY

text: profile by purchasing credit protection against obligors in an industry where an
label: BODY

text: undesirable concentration of exposures exists and to further diversify their credit risk by
label: BODY

text: selling protection on entities in other industries where the institution has little or no
label: BODY

text: exposure.  Like other financial derivatives, when used properly, credit derivatives can
label: BODY

text: help to diversify credit risk, improve earnings, and lower the risk profile of an institution.
label: BODY

text: The credit derivatives market experienced significant growth over the previous
label: BODY

text: four years, coinciding with a period in which both interest rates and credit spreads were
label: BODY

text: historically low.  In this benign market environment, investor demand for higher yielding
label: BODY

text: products drove banks and dealer firms, in their capacity as risk intermediaries, to
label: BODY

text: structure investment products that sometimes included a credit derivatives component.
label: BODY

text: For example, collateralized debt obligations may contain both cash credit instruments,
label: BODY

text: such as loans and bonds, as well as credit derivatives as the source of underlying
label: BODY

text: exposures.
label: BODY

text: Based upon financial information from quarterly call report data, the credit
label: BODY

text: derivatives market among all U.S. insured commercial banks totals more than $16 trillion
label: BODY

text: in notional exposure as of March 31, 2008, up from $1.0 trillion at year-end 2003.2  This
label: BODY

text: compares with a total notional amount of $180.3 trillion for all derivatives in U.S. insured
label: BODY

text: commercial banks at the end of the first quarter of 2008.  Credit derivatives have grown
label: BODY

text: at a compounded annual growth rate of 100% since 2003, while total notional derivatives
label: BODY

text: have grown at a rate of 21% over the same period.  It is important to note that the total
label: BODY

text: notional amount is not a good proxy for risk in derivatives contracts, but generally is
label: BODY

text: indicative of levels of business volumes.
label: BODY

text: The primary derivatives-related risks focused on by the OCC are credit risk, price
label: BODY

text: risk, and operational risk.  Credit risk in derivatives transactions arises from the exposure
label: BODY

text: that exists to the counterparty in the transaction.  This counterparty credit risk is
label: BODY

text: significant and varies over time because it changes as market factors change.  Banks
label: BODY

text: therefore use models to estimate how much exposure they will have to a counterparty
label: BODY

text: over the life of a portfolio of derivatives contracts, as well as shorter time intervals, as
label: BODY

text: 2 OCC’s Quarterly Report on Bank Trading and Derivatives Activities - First Quarter 2008.
label: BODY

text: appropriate.  During the last twelve months, financial institutions experienced a
label: BODY

text: significant growth in current credit exposure, driven by decreasing interest rates,
label: BODY

text: widening credit spreads, and ongoing market volatility.  At the end of the first quarter, net
label: BODY

text: current credit exposure from all derivatives reported by insured U.S. banks was $465
label: BODY

text: billion, 50% higher than in the fourth quarter and 159% higher than a year ago.  Gross
label: BODY

text: counterparty exposures from credit derivatives have grown even more rapidly, increasing
label: BODY

text: 86% in the first quarter, and 500% over the past 12 months.
label: BODY

text: Unlike credit risk, price risk in derivatives activities – that is, changes in the
label: BODY

text: market value of derivatives contracts – in the large national banks has traditionally been
label: BODY

text: low because of their primary role as financial intermediaries.  For example, the current
label: BODY

text: credit risk exposure for the three largest national banks’ derivatives activities was $311
label: BODY

text: billion as of the end of the first quarter and by comparison, the quarterly average Value at
label: BODY

text: Risk (VaR) reported for these three firms was $553 million.  Price risk is typically
label: BODY

text: controlled and measured by a VaR system, which is a statistical measure that banks use to
label: BODY

text: quantify the maximum loss that could occur, over a specified time horizon and at a
label: BODY

text: certain confidence interval, during normal market conditions.
label: BODY

text: Of growing concern in the OTC derivatives markets over recent years has been
label: BODY

text: the issue of operational risk, which includes losses that may occur due to back office and
label: BODY

text: process failures.  The significant growth in the credit derivatives market over the last
label: BODY

text: several years has contributed to greater levels of operational risk exposures due to system
label: BODY

text: infrastructure constraints and the potential for operational errors.  To date, we have not
label: BODY

text: identified any significant operational losses that have arisen in national banks due to back
label: BODY

text: office or processing problems, but the vulnerability is greater today due to the increase in
label: BODY

text: the size of the credit derivatives market as well as the rising levels of concern about
label: BODY

text: counterparty and underlying obligor credit quality.
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH3

text: OCC Supervision of Derivatives
label: BODY

text: As I noted earlier, derivatives activity in the U.S. commercial banking system is
label: BODY

text: dominated by a small group of large financial institutions.  The top five banks involved in
label: BODY

text: the trading of derivatives are national banks supervised by the OCC.  These five large
label: BODY

text: commercial banks represent 97% of the total commercial bank industry notional amount
label: BODY

text: and 93% of total trading revenues as of March 31, 2008.  Looking specifically at credit
label: BODY

text: derivatives, these same five institutions conduct nearly all of the trading activity for U.S.
label: BODY

text: commercial banks.
label: BODY

text: The OCC has been, and continues to be, a leader in the supervision of derivatives
label: BODY

text: activity.  In 1993, the OCC issued comprehensive guidance on the risk management
label: BODY

text: practices required to conduct the derivatives business in a safe and sound manner (OCC
label: BODY

text: Banking Circular 277).  OCC examiners conducted the first horizontal review for
label: BODY

text: derivatives activities in 1994 using that guidance.  In subsequent years, the OCC issued
label: BODY

text: additional guidance to both field examiners and bankers highlighting our supervisory
label: BODY

text: expectations regarding this activity.  In 1996, when credit derivatives were first becoming
label: BODY

text: prominent, we issued guidance to examiners on supervisory issues related to banks’ use
label: BODY

text: of these products.  These guidelines were supplemented with the “Risk Management of
label: BODY

text: Financial Derivatives” examination handbook that was issued in 1997.  In 1999, we
label: BODY

text: updated Banking Circular 277 and our examination handbook with guidance that
label: BODY

text: summarized key lessons learned from the market disruptions associated with
label: BODY

text: deterioration in Asian, Eastern European and Latin America countries and the failure of
label: BODY

text: Long Term Capital Management.  Later this year, we plan to issue another update of our
label: BODY

text: guidance to reflect lessons learned from the current  market disruption.
label: BODY

text: In 1995, the OCC began conducting a quarterly analysis of the derivatives market
label: BODY

text: using financial information from call report data submitted by national banks.  We
label: BODY

text: originally designed and published this work in an effort to help others to evaluate risks in
label: BODY

text: the national banking system and to understand the risk profile of these institutions with
label: BODY

text: regard to trading activities.  In addition, this analysis allows us to identify trends in
label: BODY

text: derivatives activity or potential risk management concerns systemically and for
label: BODY

text: individual institutions, which we then discuss with our field staff.
label: BODY

text: The foundation of the OCC’s supervisory efforts in the derivatives area is our
label: BODY

text: continuous, on-site presence of examiners at each of our largest banks.  Supervisory
label: BODY

text: strategies are developed for each institution that are risk-based and focused on the more
label: BODY

text: complex banking activities.  Our risk-based supervision is flexible, allowing strategies to
label: BODY

text: be revised to reflect the changing risk profile of the supervised institutions.
label: BODY

text: Our supervisory goal is to ensure banks have sound risk governance processes
label: BODY

text: given the nature of their risk-taking activities.  At these large banks, resident teams of
label: BODY

text: OCC specialists in capital markets and credit risk, supplemented by PhD economists
label: BODY

text: trained in quantitative finance, engage in evaluations of the suite of risks arising from
label: BODY

text: derivatives activities in general, and also credit derivatives activities specifically.  This
label: BODY

text: process involves regular monitoring of risk positions as well as periodic, targeted
label: BODY

text: examinations of specific trading areas or business operations including credit derivatives.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of our targeted examinations is to validate that management has appropriate
label: BODY

text: practices in place to identify, measure, monitor and control trading risks.  We evaluate
label: BODY

text: the integrity and effectiveness of their risk management systems, and perform
label: BODY

text: transactional testing.  We also evaluate the level of operational risk associated with
label: BODY

text: trading activities and the appropriateness of position valuations and financial reporting.
label: BODY

text: Our supervisory conclusions, including any risk management concerns, are
label: BODY

text: communicated directly to bank senior management.  Thus, not only is there ongoing
label: BODY

text: evaluation, but there is also a process for timely and effective corrective action when
label: BODY

text: needed.
label: BODY

text: III.
label: HH3

text: Strengthening the Credit Derivatives Infrastructure
label: BODY

text: As the volume of credit derivatives activities increased in recent years, there were
label: BODY

text: early warning signs that the system infrastructure, with its manual processing
label: BODY

text: environment for trade confirmations, was not keeping pace.  The early warning signs
label: BODY

text: arose in the form of metrics released by the International Swaps and Derivatives
label: BODY

text: Association (ISDA) in its annual margin survey which showed deteriorating trends with
label: BODY

text: respect to the volume and length of time that confirmations were remaining outstanding
label: BODY

text: in all derivatives portfolios, but significantly in credit derivatives space.
label: BODY

text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York convened a group of global supervisors
label: BODY

text: and key market participants in September 2005 to begin what has become an ongoing
label: BODY

text: dialogue on over-the-counter derivatives infrastructure issues.  This initiative and
label: BODY

text: continual dialogue between supervisors and the industry has driven significant market
label: BODY

text: improvements in a relatively short time horizon.  Collectively, supervisors have focused
label: BODY

text: industry attention on reducing the volume of outstanding confirmation backlogs while
label: BODY

text: increasing automation to ensure a stronger financial market infrastructure going forward.
label: BODY

text: As a result of this effort, we have seen an average reduction of 86% of outstanding
label: BODY

text: confirmations greater than thirty days among participants from initial peaks.  This effort
label: BODY

text: has been aided by the 2005 ISDA Novations Protocol, which reinforced industry
label: BODY

text: requirements to obtain the proper consent of affected parties when processing transferred
label: BODY

text: or novated contracts.  Similarly, automation of credit derivatives has more than doubled
label: BODY

text: since September 2005, such that approximately 91% of all trades are now processed
label: BODY

text: electronically.
label: BODY

text: This collaborative effort has delivered other significant milestones in industry
label: BODY

text: infrastructure improvements.  The industry developed a trade information warehouse that
label: BODY

text: holds records of many legacy and current credit derivatives trades.  This centralized trade
label: BODY

text: information should aid in future trading, quarterly payments and credit event
label: BODY

text: management.  It has already helped in early stage central settlement of quarterly premium
label: BODY

text: payments by netting those payments and thereby reducing the dollar flow of cash
label: BODY

text: payments by approximately 98%.
label: BODY

text: Despite this improvement, however, supervisors recognized last summer that
label: BODY

text: bank processing platforms were still sensitive to volume changes, as evidenced by rising
label: BODY

text: confirmation backlogs resulting from the volume spike that occurred at the beginning of
label: BODY

text: the current turmoil in credit markets.  As a result, bank supervisors redoubled efforts to
label: BODY

text: reduce confirmation backlogs, and shifted the focus to front-office initiatives to address
label: BODY

text: the scale issues exposed by last year’s market turmoil.  The front-office focus emphasizes
label: BODY

text: the need for dealers to routinely match and clear trades on the trade date, and to
label: BODY

text: maximize efficiency through standardization and automation.
label: BODY

text: As the primary regulator for national banks, the OCC has been an active
label: BODY

text: participant in this interagency effort.  For the institutions we supervise, the OCC has been
label: BODY

text: responsible for evaluating the monthly operational risk reports, identifying systemic risk
label: BODY

text: issues, and discussing implementation issues.  We have provided input to the industry
label: BODY

text: group regarding the adequacy of the industry-wide solutions and commitments, and the
label: BODY

text: development of appropriate risk metrics.  The OCC participates in regular conference
label: BODY

text: calls with supervisors from around the globe to discuss industry progress and to reinforce
label: BODY

text: the infrastructure improvement goals.
label: BODY

text: The recent joint meeting among supervisors and key derivatives market
label: BODY

text: participants on June 9, 2008, involved the discussion of several newer initiatives and
label: BODY

text: resulted in us reaching agreement on an expanded set of future goals.  The industry is in
label: BODY

text: the process of developing a new commitment letter to supervisors that will address new
label: BODY

text: processing goals, a central counterparty clearinghouse, a credit event management
label: BODY

text: mechanism, a reduction of outstanding trade volumes via multilateral trade terminations,
label: BODY

text: and an extension of the project across other derivatives markets including interest rate,
label: BODY

text: equities, foreign exchange and commodity derivatives.
label: BODY

text: IV.
label: HH3

text: Central Counterparties and Exchanges
label: BODY

text: As I noted earlier, bank derivative trading activities pose material counterparty
label: BODY

text: credit and operational risks.  In the interest of bank safety and soundness, as well as for
label: BODY

text: the health of the entire financial system, the OCC encourages market-based efforts to
label: BODY

text: promptly reduce these risks.  The OCC does not have a position, however, on the specific
label: BODY

text: format or vehicle to achieve that objective, provided that it effectively reduces these
label: BODY

text: credit and operational risks.
label: BODY

text: One initiative under consideration by supervisors and industry participants is the
label: BODY

text: development of a central counterparty for the clearing of credit derivatives.  This is a
label: BODY

text: concept that would enhance risk mitigation by providing for multilateral netting among
label: BODY

text: the major dealers.  A central counterparty could facilitate the management of
label: BODY

text: counterparty credit risk exposures and reduce operational risks across the industry.  The
label: BODY

text: central counterparty would manage both counterparty credit and operational risks by
label: BODY

text: truncating the volume of trades among counterparties via a multilateral netting process
label: BODY

text: and by implementing forward-looking margin requirements.  Multilateral netting permits
label: BODY

text: long and short positions among multiple counterparties to “net down” to a much smaller
label: BODY

text: volume of open transactions because the central counterparty serves as the seller to every
label: BODY

text: buyer, and the buyer to every seller.  With a smaller volume of contracts to be tracked
label: BODY

text: and managed left outstanding, the clearinghouse helps to reduce operational risk.
label: BODY

text: A clearinghouse model provides a central counterparty and involves ownership
label: BODY

text: guaranty funding and participant margin structure to protect against counterparty credit
label: BODY

text: risk.  Given a variety of system, standardization, risk analysis, and pricing issues that may
label: BODY

text: need to be resolved, a clearinghouse might initially have limited application to only index
label: BODY

text: trades and there may be additional challenges that would need to be addressed as it
label: BODY

text: progresses to other credit derivatives products.
label: BODY

text: Another issue under consideration is an exchange concept for credit derivatives.
label: BODY

text: It is our understanding that the introduction of an exchange structure to the OTC credit
label: BODY

text: derivatives market would require significant standardization and potentially transform the
label: BODY

text: nature of that market.  Given the proven success of the OTC derivatives markets to
label: BODY

text: deliver customized financial products, and current market-based efforts underway to
label: BODY

text: address credit and operational risks, we do not see a need for the OCC to favor one
label: BODY

text: solution over another.
label: BODY

text: Legislative Oversight Evaluation
label: HH1

text: The OCC has had a longstanding position that we do not believe that OTC
label: BODY

text: derivatives products need to be regulated, in part because the vast majority of significant
label: BODY

text: participants in these markets are regulated.  As I have described, the OCC carefully
label: BODY

text: monitors the participation of national banks in OTC derivatives markets and we spend
label: BODY

text: considerable resources, individually and collectively with other supervisors, providing
label: BODY

text: direct supervisory oversight to the largest national banks who actively participate in these
label: BODY

text: markets.
label: BODY

text: More broadly, the OCC works closely with other domestic and international
label: BODY

text: regulators to exchange information and coordinate the supervision of key market players
label: BODY

text: that could pose systemic risks to the financial system.  In addition to the collaborative
label: BODY

text: credit derivatives infrastructure project previously discussed, the OCC is an active
label: BODY

text: participant in the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets, the Senior
label: BODY

text: Supervisors Group, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the Financial Stability
label: BODY

text: Forum, and the Joint Forum of senior bank, insurance, and securities supervisors that
label: BODY

text: Comptroller Dugan chairs.  These working groups recently released a number of reports,
label: BODY

text: discussing key lessons learned and setting forth recommendations for financial
label: BODY

text: institutions and their supervisors to enhance market and institutional resilience.3  We
label: BODY

text: contributed to and support these initiatives.
label: BODY

text: Through these various mechanisms, we are satisfied that we have the necessary
label: BODY

text: tools at our disposal to effectively supervise these banking activities and as such, we do
label: BODY

text: not see a need for legislative intervention to supplement our ability to regulate the credit
label: BODY

text: derivatives of national banks.
label: BODY

text: VI.
label: HH3

text: Conclusion
label: H1

text: As I described earlier, it is our belief that credit derivatives, when used properly,
label: BODY

text: can help financial institutions to diversify credit exposures, improve earnings, and lower
label: BODY

text: their risk profiles.  Large national banks that are active participants in this market, serve
label: BODY

text: primarily as financial intermediaries for bank clients interested is achieving a particular
label: BODY

text: credit risk profile or exposure.  The OCC closely monitors the activities of these national
label: BODY

text: banks to ensure that they have appropriate senior management oversight, robust risk
label: BODY

text: management systems and the necessary infrastructure to support these risk intermediation
label: BODY

text: activities.  While the growth of the credit derivatives market has placed visible strains on
label: BODY

text: some firms’ operational infrastructures, the OCC and other global supervisors are
label: BODY

text: actively working with industry participants to resolve these issues, and we have seen
label: BODY

text: meaningful progress in these efforts to-date.
label: BODY

text: 3 Senior Supervisors Group Report, “Observations on Risk Management Practices,” at
label: BODY

text: http://www.newyorkfed.org/newsevents/news/banking/2008/SSG_Risk_Mgt_doc_final.pdf;
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: http://www.newyorkfed.org/newsevents/news/banking/2008/SSG_Leading_Practice_Disclosures.pdf ;
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY
